Now black is defending, but he has a very good center and wins me in developement. Concretely, if I had my Nb1 out of there, I would be able to bring my rook to d1, improving my position. h3 WAS a waste of a time, after all.

The conventional plan Nb-e2, o-o-o, Nc4 looks ok, but just a little slow. So I tried to further limit black's moves, controlling the good f5.
Black castles the right way. My forces are aimed to the queenside, and this correctly opens the way for the rook's action.
This advance is not good for black until he doesn't threat f2 seriously. It is better for him to keep the central tension and control.

This loses a pawn, but a cost of a massive pieces exchange, and I'm not sure it was whortwhile.

The only "advantage" of my position is that the queen is in front of the rook, so I can challenge it with N or Rf3 if he takes.

How to proceed? It's really a nasty situation for me. Probably, I had to act trying to blockade the kingside and plan on the queenside, instead, taking a5 after reinforcing a2, etc.

I was trying all the time to go Nc4, but nothing hanged behind. I even though about a sac for two pawns, but I didn't dare. Anyway, with this plan, as often happens in chess, he gets a hole by losing one.
Now it becomes more interesting, but I must recognize HIS "hole" is larger than mine. But now I AM threatening Nc4. Only it is too late.
Nc4, gxh+ then it start to rain.
Interestingly enough, black didn't take e3 inmediately: QxR, Qe2+ and it's not for a blitz game to see if it wins, even if I suspect it does for black.
